ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: latin american culture and language skills
Furthered my speaking, reading, and writing skills in Spanish. Gained a lot of knowledge about unique components of the culture and history of Latin America,
Reading, writing, and conversing in Spanish about topics like politics, art, and literature

This course gave me the opportunity to learn and practice my written and oral Spanish! It provided different methods of learning and opportunities to speak/present/listen/discuss/read/write/etc through projects and assignments. I loved the themes of the class (there were five) and how they gave us complex and interesting things to discuss.

Practice and improved my Spanish language skills; became much more comfortable with spontaneous conversation without notes or preparation; developed my essay-writing skills; had the chance, for the first time, to debate and analyze complex topics in Spanish

I sharpened my oral and written Spanish skills, specifically in terms of fluidity in both areas. All the presentation and speaking opportunities provided the time I needed to improve. Additionally, the exchange program was great in terms of comprehension and helped me gain insights into Latin American culture.
I'm now far more confident communicating in Spanish with others; gained a solid grasp of Latin American culture/history/current issues as well as understanding of a lot of grammatical concepts

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Leon is lovely and you will walk away from this course being better at Spanish

This was my favorite class I have taken at Yale thus far. The unit projects were excellent, and Prof. Leon guided in-class discussion in a way that yielded a lot of critical thinking and interesting perspectives being shared.

Strengths: engagement with a variety of Spanish-language sources such as films, articles, and novels; abundant opportunities to build Spanish reading, writing, and speaking skills through projects, presentations, essays, and classroom discussion; super clear feedback from Profesora Len. Weaknesses: I feel like the grammatical review could be emphasized more with possibly more review resources offered, since some students like me may be slightly rusty on Spanish grammar going into the class

Strengths:
-great themes
-generally good amount of homework and project work
-great to have class three days/week for under an hour (frequency helped with practicing my spanish more often)
-it was cool having conversation partners in Peru to talk with every week
-the guest speakers were also so interesting
-I loved having small group and large group discussions with my classmates

Weaknesses:
-sometimes the requirements for assignments were not as clear as they could be
-I think there could be more instruction on grammar if it is going to be tested (often the one page explanation of the grammar concept wasn't enough)

Strengths: great field trip to YUAG, two amazing speakers (Roy Brown and Alberto Belaunde), and a Peruvian Zoom Pal (I learned so much!), class taught entirely in Spanish; each unit deals with a very interesting different topic and each contains different types of assignments; project-based assignments; professor accessible during office hours. Weaknesses: high work volume, could have used a few more lessons about grammar prior to online grammar homework assignments.

This course had a variety of opportunities to practice different skills relating to the Spanish language. There was some confusion about where homework was posted at times but other than that I enjoyed the content and projects.

Strengths: student participation-oriented, professor was great (also so sweet), taught in Spanish so your command of the language improves through the constant practice, covers lots of different areas

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Professor Leon is lovely and you will improve your Spanish. there's not a ton of grammar review though so if you're wanting more focus on the fundamentals of the language then be prepared to do a bit more review on your own

Absolutely-- it is a fair bit of work and you'll need to be pretty engaged with the class to get a lot out of it, but in my opinion it is totally worth it. I was not at all bothered by the fact that it met three days a week, and looked forward to this class a lot because of the variety of fascinating topics covered.

Absolutely. By emphasizing engagement with native material (articles, novels, films) rather than memorizing grammar and vocab, this class helped me grow my Spanish reading, writing, and speaking skills more than five years of high school Spanish.
Definitely! It was a great way to practice and improve my Spanish for practical application, which was exactly what I was looking for.

Yes, if you care about honing your Spanish speaking, writing, and comprehension skills and want to learn about Spanish culture and important social topics through project-based learning in a seminar-style immersion environment chock full with discussion, this is for you. I wouldn't call this class a gut.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in deepening their understanding of Spanish once they know the basics. I feel like I am almost fluent thanks to this course.
Absolutely, it is perfect for becoming a fluent and confident Spanish communicator

extras.title: SPAN 150 01 - Adv Oral and Writ Com in Span
